Frontispiece portrait engr. by William Dolle after William Faithorne, dated 1671; it is sometimes claimed that this engraving was first published in Milton's Artis logicae plenior institutio (1672), & it is often found in copies of that work, but the plate is too large to have been designed for it.
Francis Blackburne, in his Memoirs of Thomas Hollis (1780), p. *584*, records an edition in twelve books dated 1672, probably a ghost, inferred from the date of the portrait.
Also reissued with t.p. dated 1675; see the Univ. of Illinois exhibition catalogue, Collection of first editions of Milton's works (1953), item 53

docs.loc_call_num_subject: Philosophy. Psychology. Religion -- Islam. Bahai Faith. Theosophy, etc. -- Islam -- General works on Islam
note: With special title-pages for parts I-II, III, and IV.

The first two parts were originally published (Utrecht, 1705) under title: De religione mohammedica libri duo. The material, including translations of many passages, was drawn from original sources, chiefly from Abū Shujāʻ. cf. Quérard. La France litt., 1835, t. 7, p. 512.
The third part, first published in Latin (Oxoniae, 1690) under title: Tractus Alberti Bovovii ... de Turcorum liturgia, includes notes by Thomas Hyde.

The fourth part, by Mathurin Veyssière de Lacroze, was first published in his Dissertations historiques sur divers sujets (Rotterdam, 1707) cf. Quérard. La France litt., 1800, t. 4, p. 381. The present translation includes "a letter from Mr. Leibnitz to the author" (p. 245-254)
Pages [95-96], advertisements, with catchword on p. [96].
"Historical and critical reflections" includes (p. 245-254) a letter from Leibniz

Fifth in a series of twelve collections issued in 1688 under the general title: A collection of papers relating to the present juncture of affairs in England; and reissued in 1689 under title: A compleat collection of papers, in twelve parts, relating to the great revolutions in England and Scotland.

In this state, the seventh piece in the collection, with caption title "A letter to the King, when Duke of York ...", is mispaged 1-8 and missigned A⁴, & has separate imprint on p.8 (i.e. 32) "London, Printed and are to be sold by Richard Janeway, 1688." This piece, signed at end "Philanax Verax [pseud.]", was first published in 1681 with title "A letter to His Royal Highness ...", & should not be confused with the similarly titled work by Sir Leoline Jenkins
Includes bibliographical references

"An advertisement from the bookseller," signed N[athaniel]. P[onder]., on the verso of the t.p. notes the appearance of a "counterfeit impression in 12⁰ under the title and pretence of the 2d edition corrected."
An attack on Samuel Parker's preface to "Bishop Bramhall's vindication of himself and the episcopal clergy," which was answered by Richard Leigh in "The transposer rehearsed."
This is Marvell's first contribution to the controversy over Villiers' The rehearsal. Cf. MacDonald, H. John Dryden, p. 193 and 196.

note: Attributed to Harrison by Wing and NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Advertisements: [1] p. at end.

Preface signed: T.H[arrison?].", possibly as editor, since it appears from "The author's advertisement" (p. [32]) that the printer is not the author. Harrison published and perhaps compiled an enlarged version under titles "Vox populi, vox Dei: being the true maxims of government" (1709) & "The judgment of whole kingdoms and nations, concerning the rights ... of kings, and ... of the people" (1710); cf. Morgan L 105, accepting the ascription of the later version to Harrison as "the most likely", though confusing the first title with "Vox populi vox Dei; or The voice of the people, the voice of God" [1719], ascribed to Samuel Brewster the elder.

Variously ascribed to Daniel Defoe by Halkett & Laing (but not by Moore); to Charles Povey by the DNB, confusingly citing the subtitle of "The judgment of whole kingdoms and nations" (1710), which is not Povey's (cf. F. B. Relton, An account of the fire insurance companies (1893), p. 463); & to John Dunton & John, lord Somers. "The doctrine of passive obedience and jure divino disproved", advertised on p. [32] as by the same author, is wrongly ascribed in Halkett & Laing to George Hickes, apparently by some confusion with a reply, "The doctrine of passive obedience ... disproved ... answered and refuted", published by Randall Taylor in 1689.
Many sentences are plagiarized without acknowledgement from Locke's second treatise of government; cf. the paragraph on p. 2-3 with Locke's Two treatises [1689], II, secs. 4, 13 & 127

The first edition; another edition printed the same year, differs slightly in title and errata.

The "Scriptures and reasons" (p. 1-6) is a part--the 6th-9th chapters--of a work printed in 1620, entitled "A most humble supplication of the King's Majesty's loyal subjects, ready to testify all civil obedience ..." signed by "Your Majesty's loyal subjects unjustly called Anabaptists", a work attributed to John Murton. The "Model of church and civil power" "examined and answered" in the last fifty-six chapters, is probably not that ascribed to Richard Mather, but an earlier one, never printed, drawn up in accordance with the Act of the General court, March 4, 1634, "by the elders and brethern of every church within this jurisdiction". cf. The bloudy tenent of persecution. ed. by S. L. Caldwell, Providence, 1867; and O. S. Straus, Roger Williams, New York, 1894

"The account..." is "A true account of what was transacted in the assembly of the united ministers of Devon and Cornwal"; NUC pre-56 NP0184750 attributes it to Josiah Eveleigh, probably confusing A true account... with Eveleigh's Account of the reasons why many citizens of Exon... -- Includes the text of the 6 May paper subscribed by Peirce, Hallet & 17 others in which they deny the charge of Arianism (p.37-38); a "Postscript" in which Peirce describes his parentage and youth to disprove charges that he was a Jesuit, born in France or Spain (p.41-46); "Publish'd by the same author" (p.[47-48]); and "Just publish'd, by another hand" (foot of p.[48]) -- Part of the Arian controversy at Exeter

Vol. 5 includes: Some account of the abbey church of Tewkesbury ... By Thomas Amyot.--Notes and remarks, by ... William Capon, to accompany his plan of the ancient palace of Westminster.--Some remarks on the pillar or obelisk at Forres, Morayshire, called Sueno's stone. [By J.H. Markland].--Observations on several ancient swords of state belonging to the earldom of Chester: in a letter from George Ormerod.--Some account of the ancient and present state of the abbey of St. Mary, York ... By the Rev. Charles Wellbeloved.--Observations on the church of St. Mary le Bow, chiefly relating to its original structure: By George Gwilt.--Memoir, on the antiquities discovered by Edward Rudge ... in excavating the ruins of the abbey church of Evesham; by Edward John Rudge.

Vol. 6 includes: Remarks on the Louterell Psalter, an illuminated manuscript of the first part of the fourteenth century. Communicated by John Gage Rokewode.--A memoir on the Painted chamber in the palace at Westminster ... by John Gage Rokewode.--Notice of a drawing in the Royal library at Windsor, representing the chair of St. Peter at Rome. By Arthur Ashpitel.--Remarks on illuminations in some Irish Biblical manuscripts. Communicated by the Rev. James Henthorn Todd.--Two memoirs on the "Evangelia quatuor", once belonging to the abbey of Lindau, and now to the Earl of Ashburnham: I. The golden jewelled covers, by Alexander Nesbit. II. The ms. text by Edward Maunde Thompson.

This work was commenced in 1718, the plates of vol. 1 bearing dates from 1718-1747. Vol. 3 has imprint "1796. Reprinted 1799." Vol. 1-3 are stamped with the arms of the Duke of Roxburghe and contain the book-plate of Henry Godwin

"An essay on natural religion, as opposed to divine revelation erroneously attributed to Dryden", has special title page, dated 1746.
"An essay on natural religion ... " (1 ℓ., 12 p.), here wrongly attributed to Dryden, appears in "The oracles of reason" as a letter to Blount signed" A.W.
Cf. Macdonald, Hugh. John Dryden; a bibliography. Oxford, 1939, p. 184.
Chiefly extracts from Blount's The oracles of reason.
"Postscript to the Deists religion" (p. 10-15) is from Charles Gildon's preface to The oracles of reason.
"Remarks on the immortality of the soul" (p. 16-25) is a letter from Blount to John Wilmot, earl of Rochester (Feb. 7, 1680), with additions on p. 16 & 25 to render it contemporary.
"De anima" (p. 26-27) is by Henry Blount
docs.sub_title: in a letter to that excellent physician, the late Dr. Sydenham : to which are annex'd some curious remarks on the immortality of the soul : and an essay by the celebrated poet, John Dryden : to prove that natural religion is alone necessary to salvation, in opposition to all divine revelation : N.B. This last piece contains the strongest arguments against the necessity and advantages of a divine revelation, ever yet published ...

A forgery of STC 22103.7. The engraved title-page has a donkey-litter with motto "Simul complectar omnia" above & to the left of Gondomar's right shoulder, and "The second edition" to the right of his head.

Structure of first quires is obscure. A1 (title page) is followed by dedication (a 2-leaf insert signed []̜A1-2); A2 has illustration and beginning of text. Leaves continue "A3", unsigned, B1-3. STC says the unsigned leaf is B1 and B2-4 are missigned 1-3, in which case ¹A4 is unaccounted for and apparently cancelled. Pagination is continuous. Quire F should be bound 4, 1, 2, 3.
In this edition, p.23, ℓ.1 begins "become"
